questions.text:
Which among the given muscles converge and interlace in the perineal body?
  1. Bulbospongiosus
  2. Deep transverse perenei
  3. Ischiocavernosus
  4. Levator ani
  5. Internal urethral sphincter
questions.solution:
Bulbospongiosus, Deep transverse perenei, and Levator ani are the muscles that converge and interlace in the perineal body.

The ten muscles of the perineum that converge and interlace in the perineal body are:

  • Two unpaired 
    • External anal sphincter
    • Longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Four paired
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Superficial transverse perenei
    • Deep transverse perenei
    • Levator ani

The perineal body is the central fibrous skeleton of the perineum. It is situated in the medial plane about 1.25 cm in front of the anal margin and close to the bulb of the penis. In females, the sphincter urethro-vaginalis is also attached to the perineal body. The perineal body has a pyramidal shape in males and a wedge shape in females.

The perineal body is innervated by the perineal nerve, the larger and inferior terminal branch of the perineal pudendal nerve. It is directed forward under the internal pudendal artery. 

The perineal body supports the pelvic organs in females and it may get damaged during parturition or childbirth. This may result in prolapse of :

  • Urinary bladder
  • Uterus
  • Ovaries
  • Rectum

The image below shows the muscles of the perineum:

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: You are a medical student examining a slide of nerve tissue. You find neurons with the structure shown in the image given below. In which of the sites are such neurons most likely to be found?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a single process of axons from the cell body that splits into two, of which, both function as axons. This structure is suggestive of a pseudo-unipolar neuron, which is seen in the dorsal root ganglia.

In pseudounipolar neurons, out of the two axons, one goes to the skin or muscles and another to the spinal cord.

Other options:

Options B and C - Motor horn of the spinal cord has motor neurons and the cerebellar cortex predominantly has Purkinje cells. Both these types of neurons are examples of multipolar neurons/cells. They have one axon and many dendrites.

Cerebellar Purkinje cells have an extensive dendritic tree in a single plane. The image below shows Purkinje cells of the cerebellum:

 

The image below shows a spinal motor neuron:

 

Option D- Scarpa's or vestibular ganglion is an example of bipolar neurons.  They have two specialized processes. A dendrite carries information to the cell and an axon that transmits information from the cell. Another example is the bipolar cells of the retina.

Related Pearl: Classification of neurons based on the number of neuronal processes

 

Structure

Example

Unipolar

 

These neurons have a single process with different segments serving as receptive surfaces and releasing terminals

Neurons seen in invertebrates

Bipolar

Two processes exit from the cell body-a dendrite and an axon

Retinal bipolar ganglion cells

Pseudounipolar

Subclass of bipolar cells

As the cell develops, a single process splits into two, both of which function as axons- one going to skin or muscles and another to spinal cord

Dorsal root ganglia

Multipolar

Many processes exit from the cell body. Have one axon and many dendrites

Spinal motor neuron

Hippocampal pyramidal cells

Cerebellar Purkinje cells

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text:
Identify the correctly matched incisions?

a- Rutherford Morison

b- Pfannenstiel

c- Kocher's 

d- Lanz
questions.solution:
Abdominal incisions illustrated above are:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision, (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to infero-medial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is Battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for cases with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. 
  • 6 is paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision is a straight transverse skin incision slightly higher than Pfannenstiel (5-6 cm|) from the upper border of the pubic symphysis. 
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison's incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision. It is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocausal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - A transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for urological,  gynecological, and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis for a few weeks. He was started on an oral antifungal drug acting on point A in the following diagram. This drug is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis is suggestive of tinea capitis. The drug acting on point A in the above diagram is griseofulvin. 

Griseofulvin is a fungistatic antifungal agent. Griseofulvin disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting microtubule function and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle. 

It is administered orally and its absorption is improved when taken with a fatty meal. It gets deposited in the keratin precursor cells and binds tightly to keratin. Thereby, it provides prolonged resistance to fungal invasion. 

They are only effective against dermatophytes Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis and tenia pedis.

Griseofulvin induces hepatic CYPs and thereby increases the rate of metabolism of warfarin and low-estrogen oral contraceptive agents. Side effects of griseofulvin include headache, gastrointestinal disturbance, and hepatotoxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in the fungal membrane and forms pores or channels (point C) in the fungal cell membrane and allows the leakage of cytosolic molecules and ions, leading to loss of membrane integrity.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides braziliensis, Aspergillus, Penicillium marneffei, Fusarium, and Mucorales.

Option B: Itraconazole is triazole that inhibits 14-alpha-sterol demethylase (point D) and impairs the biosynthesis of ergosterol which leads to accumulation of the toxic product 14 alpha-methyl-3,6-diol resulting in growth arrest. 

Itraconazole is the drug of choice for nonmeningeal infections due to B. dermatitidis, H. capsulatum, P. brasiliensis, and Coccidioides immitis. The drug also is useful in the therapy of invasive aspergillosis particularly after the infection has been treated with amphotericin B.

Option C: Terbinafine inhibits fungal squalene epoxidase (point B) and reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. They are more effective against nail onychomycosis than itraconazole.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text:
A 12- year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever and colicky abdominal pain. Stool examination revealed the following worms. Which of the following are incorrect about this organism

1. Embryonated egg-containing Rhabditiform larvae are infective
2. Embryonated egg-containing Filiform larvae are infective
3. Fertilised eggs are always bile stained
4. Man is the only natural host
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and image are suggestive of ascariasis due to  Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). 2 is incorrect. 

Ascaris lumbricoides are the most common of human helminths which are distributed worldwide and they are the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine. Adult worms live in the small intestine. 

The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior. Adult male worms are little smaller than female worms. 

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris that contain the infective rhabditiform larva. 

Initial exposure to larvae creates a very heavy larval load and is usually asymptomatic but, reinfection causes an intense cellular reaction to the migrating larvae in the lungs and infiltration of eosinophils and present as Ascaris pneumonia characterized by low-grade fever, dry cough, and asthmatic wheezing. 

They often have blood-tinged sputum that contains Charcot-Leyden crystals and larvae occasionally. This condition is termed Loeffler's syndrome.

In children, they interfere with proper digestion and absorption of food and result in protein-energy malnutrition and vitamin A deficiency.

Masses of the worms cause luminal occlusion and may stimulate reflex peristalsis causing recurrent and severe colicky abdominal pain. The mass formed by the clumping of worms in the intestine fills the lumen and causes volvulus, intussusception, intestinal obstruction, or perforation. 

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in feces. Fertilized eggs are always bile stained. 

Effective and safe drugs for the treatment of ascariasis include:

  • Pyrantel pamoate 11mg/kg once and is safe in pregnancy
  • Albendazole 400 mg once
  • Mebendazole 100 mg twice daily for 3 days
  • Ivermectin 150-200 mcg/kg once

Nasogastric suction, intervenous fluid administration, and installation of piperazine through the nasogastric tube can be used for partial intestinal obstruction. Immediate surgical intervention is required in cases of complete obstruction.

  1. Adult worms live in the lumen of the small intestine. A female produces eggs which are passed with the feces 
  2. Unfertilized eggs may be ingested but are not infective.
  3. Larvae develop infectivity within fertile eggs after 18 days to several weeks, depending on the environmental conditions (optimum: moist, warm, shaded soil).
  4. After infective eggs are swallowed and the larvae hatch
  5. The larvae invade the intestinal mucosa and are carried via the portal, then systemic circulation to the lungs.
  6. The larvae mature further in the lungs (10 to 14 days), penetrate the alveolar walls, ascend the bronchial tree to the throat, and are swallowed
  7. Upon reaching the small intestine, they develop into adult worms. Between 2 and 3 months are required from ingestion of the infective eggs to oviposition by the adult female. Adult worms can live for 1 to 2 years.

Related Pearl: Commonly known names of some important parasites

a. Trematodes

 b. Cestodes

 c. Nematodes:

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism.  His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels.  Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe hypothyroidism with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in severe hypothyroidism can be due to poor response of the central nervous system to hypoxia and hypercapnia, as well as reduced strength of the respiratory muscles.

Other causes for diminished CNS drive to breathe:

  • Drug overdose
  • Brainstem injury
  • Sleep-disordered breathing 

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to

  • Impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis)
  • Respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue)

The overall load on the respiratory system that can facilitate type 2 respiratory failure can be classified as follows:

  • Resistive loads, as in bronchospasm
  • Loads due to reduced lung compliance as in alveolar oedema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
  • Loads due to reduced chest wall compliance as in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
  • Loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements as in pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

Treatment:

Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure remains the mainstay treatment for type 2 respiratory failure. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask and avoiding endotracheal intubation often stabilise patients with type 2 respiratory failure. This approach is beneficial in treating patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Low pO2

Normal/ low pCO2

High (pAO2-paO2)

Sepsis

Gastric aspiration

Pneumonia

Near-drowning

Multiple blood transfusions

Pancreatitis
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Low pO2

High pCO2

Normal (pAO2-paO2)

Drug overdose

Brainstem injury

Sleep-disordered breathing

Severe hypothyroidism

Myasthenia gravis

Guillain-Barre syndrome

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

 

pO2- partial pressure of oxygen

pCO2- partial pressure of carbon dioxide

(pAO2-paO2)- alveolar- arterial oxygen gradient

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of recurrent headaches for the past few months. A characteristic sign was noted on the MRI, as seen in the image below, and a provisional diagnosis of meningioma was made. Which of the following are the other conditions showing this sign on the MRI?

1) Schwanomma

2) Sarcoidosis

3) Primary CNS lymphomas

4) Craniopharyngioma

5) Lipoma
questions.solution:
The MRI shows a dural tail sign, which is commonly seen in meningioma. However, it may also be seen in the following nonmeningiomatous lesions:

  1. Schwannoma
  2. Metastases
  3. Sarcoidosis
  4. Primary CNS lymphomas
  5. Chloroma

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumor, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases)

Three criteria should be met for a positive dural tail sign:

  • The tail should be seen on two successive images arising from the tumor.
  • The tail should taper away from the tumor.
  • The tail must enhance more than the tumor. 

The image shows Axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass, resembling a tail - hence, called the dural tail sign.

 

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a meningeal blood supply to the tumour, a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous and persistent blush.
  • CT scan usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI:
    • Capping cysts may be visible, with signal intensity (SI) similar to the CSF.
    • Vasogenic oedema is frequently seen. However, it does not correlate with tumour size.
    • Dural tail sign: It is commonly seen in meningiomas (about 60% of the cases). It is not a characteristic finding and may be seen in other conditions as mentioned above.
  • PET: Shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand. It helps in distinguishing meningiomas from similar looking lesions.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon is taking a class on various tendon repair surgeries, by using cadaveric specimens. While demonstrating a procedure on the muscle marked X, he points to a nerve that is in close proximity to this muscle. He emphasizes that damage to this nerve would result in poor function of the marked muscle and would affect the eversion of the sub-talar joint. Which nerve is the surgeon talking about?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the peroneus longus (principle evertor of the foot) since it lies in the lateral compartment. It is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve. Damage to the superficial peroneal nerve, the nerve in close proximity to this muscle, would result in loss of eversion at the sub-talar joint.

The anterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.

Contents: 

  • Tibialis anterior
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Peroneus tertius 

The lateral compartment of the leg is supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve. It consists of peroneus longus and peroneus brevis.

The posterior compartment of the leg is supplied by the tibial nerve. 

Contents:

  • Gastrocnemius
  • Soleus
  • Plantaris
  • Popliteus
  • Flexor hallucis longus
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • Tibialis posterior

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the leg and their innervation:

 

Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg and dorsum of foot

Nerve Supply

Tibialis anterior

 

 

Deep Peroneal Nerve

Extensor hallucis longus

Extensor digitorum longus

Peroneus tertius

Extensor digitorum brevis

Peroneus longus

 

Superficial Peroneal Nerve

Peroneus brevis

Superficial muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

 

Gastrocnemius

 

Tibial Nerve

Deep muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg

Tibial Nerve

Flexor hallucis longus

questions.text: A child was brought for routine follow-up of his anthropometric surveillance. On obtaining upper body segment and lower body segment measurements, you find the U/L ratio to be 1. What could be the likely age of this child, provided that he has normal development?
questions.solution:
The upper segment to lower segment (U/L) ratio in this child is 1. In normal development, the U/L ratio is 1 in children more than 7 years.

The lower segment(L) is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment(U) is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

The U/L ratio is

  • 1.7 at birth
  • 1.3 at 3 years
  • 1 after 7 years
  • 0.9 in adults

High U/L ratio:

  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia (short limb dwarfism)
  • Turner syndrome
  • Untreated congenital hypothyroidism

Low U/L ratio:

  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Morquio syndrome
  • Vertebral anomalies

Arm span:

  • Length between the tips of the middle finger of the outstretched hands is the arm span.
  • It is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth; it equals height at 11 y and thereafter is slightly greater than height (usually<1 cm).

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is crying uncontrollably and is complaining of ear pain. He has a high-grade fever, cold, and nose block. The otoscopic examination showed the following finding. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of severe ear pain, fever, and cold with the otoscopic image showing red and bulging tympanic membrane are likely to be acute suppurative otitis media. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of this condition. Other organisms that can cause these are:

  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Clinical features: The child may present with a cold, fever, and earache. If the tympanic membrane ruptures, ear discharge might also be there.

In the stage of presuppuration, there might be a leash of blood vessels that appear along with the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane giving it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the entire tympanic membrane becomes red.

Management:

Since the most common organism responsible are Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenza, antibiotics should be started. The effective drugs in acute otitis media are ampicillin (50 mg/kg/day in four divided doses) and amoxicillin (40 mg/kg/day in three divided doses).

Decongestant nasal drops- ephedrine, oxymetazoline, and xylometazoline nasal drops can be used to decrease the edema of the eustachian tube, and promote middle ear ventilation.

Oral nasal decongestants like pseudoephedrine in combination with an antihistamine are effective in treating nasal blockade.

Analgesics and antipyretics are used to relieve pain and fever

If there is ear discharge, it has to be mopped with sterile cotton buds. An antibiotic wick may also be inserted.

Myringotomy: It is incising the eardrum to evacuate pus and is indicated when the drum is bulging and there is acute pain, incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, persistent conductive hearing loss, and persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.

Related Pearl: Stages of acute suppurative otitis media

Stage

Throbbing pain, deafness. fever

CHL

Suppuration

and
pus formation
Excruciating earache, deafness, high fever
Bulging TM with pus
CHL
Add myringotomy to drain the pus
Resolution
TM ruptures and pus drains
Ear discharge and patient starts to feel better
Perforation in AI quadrant
CHL improves
Ear mopping with the decongestants and antibiotics
Complication
Virulent organism/poor immunity
Mastoiditis/ Infratemporal/ Intracranial complications

ET: Eustachian tube; TM: Tympanic Membrane; CHL: Conductive Hearing Loss; AI: Antero-Inferior quadrant

Related Pearl: Microbiology of the middle ear

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency following a road traffic accident. He is intoxicated and his blood alcohol level is high.  Examination revealed a fractured femur. He is posted for surgery. When compared to that in a person who is not intoxicated with alcohol, the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of sevoflurane in this patient is expected to be __________ .
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes acute alcohol intoxication in which the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of sevoflurane will be reduced when compared to a patient who is not intoxicated with alcohol.

The MAC of an inhaled anesthetic is the minimum alveolar concentration that prevents patient movement in 50% of patients in response to a standardized stimulus like a surgical incision.

Factors that affect MAC are:

Conditions increasing MAC Conditions decreasing MAC
Body temperature > 42 oC Elderly
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia, Hyperthermia with body temperature <42oC
Hypernatremia Acute alcohol intoxication
Cocaine Hypercalcemia, hyponatremia
Ephedrine Pregnancy
Acute amphetamine poisoning Anesthetics
  Sympatholytics like methyldopa, clonidine, dexmedetomidine
 
Younger age (maximum at 6 months of age) 

 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Factors increasing MAC Factors decreasing MAC No change in MAC
Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism
Acute amphetamine use  Older age (>6 months MAC decreases 6% per decade)  
Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension  
  Hypercarbia, Hypoxia, Metabolic acidosis  
  Pregnancy   

 

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC (Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient (Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. The lower the MAC, the higher is the potency.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of a chronic cough and weight loss. He has a 30-pack-years smoking history. Bronchoscopy and biopsy show the findings below. Which of the following is false about this patient's condition?

choices.text: CD56 is expressed by these tumour cells
Smokers are strongly predisposed to this condition
Hypercalcemia may be associated with this condition
Keratinization and squamous pearls can be seen in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. CD56 is not expressed by squamous cell carcinoma, it is a marker for small cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is most commonly found in men and is strongly associated with smoking. 

Squamous cell carcinoma predominantly arises in the central segmental or subsegmental bronchi. The tumor may grow into the bronchial lumen and produce an intraluminal mass. In certain cases, the bronchial obstruction may lead to atelectasis or infection. The tumor may penetrate the wall of the bronchus and infiltrate the peribronchial tissue into the carina or the mediastinum. 

This tumor may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, the most common is hypercalcemia. The symptoms could include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, lethargy, polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration.

Squamous metaplasia and dysplasia often precede frank squamous cell carcinoma. Carcinoma in-situ persists for many years and this may often be recognized on cytologic smears or in BAL fluid or brushings.

Gross appearance: The tissue is grey-white, firm, with areas of necrosis and hemorrhages. Red or yellow-white mottling and softening may be seen. The necrotic foci may cavitate. 

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of keratinization and intercellular bridges. Keratinization can be seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm. 

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

Clinical Syndromes/ 

Endocrinopathies

Major Forms of Underlying Cancer

Causal Mechanism

Cushing Syndrome

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Pancreatic carcinoma

Neural tumours

Renal carcinoma

ACTH or ACTH- like substance

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)

Small-cell carcinoma of lung

Intracranial neoplasms

Antidiuretic hormone or atrial natriuretic hormones

Hypercalcemia

Squamous cell carcinoma of lung

Breast carcinoma

Renal carcinoma

Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma

Parathyroid hormone-related protein(PTHRP), TGF-a, TNF, IL-1

Hypoglycaemia

Ovarian carcinoma

Fibrosarcoma

Other mesenchymal sarcomas

Insulin or insulin-like substance

Polycythemia

Renal carcinoma

Hepatocellular carcinoma

Erythropoietin

FGF-23

Tumor products activate clotting

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy drives a car after getting drunk at a party and injures a child walking on the pedestrian lane. The child dies on spot. The post-mortem report indicates Waddell's triad. Which of the following constitute the injuries forming Waddell's triad?
  1. Intertrochantric fracture of femur.
  2. Hood injury to the abdomen resulting in blunt trauma and liver laceration.
  3. Contralateral head trauma resulting in massive extradural hemorrhage.
  4. Tibial condylar fracture.
  5. Ipsilateral head trauma resulting in epidural hemorrhage.
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, injuries included in the Waddell's triad include 

  • Intertrochantric fracture of femur
  • Hood injury to the abdomen resulting in blunt trauma and liver laceration
  • Contralateral head trauma resulting in massive extradural hemorrhage

Waddell's Triad is a classic pattern of transportation injury seen in a pedestrian child due to motor vehicle. It comprises of:

  1. Limb fractures of femur or pelvis (never tibia or patella): This is due to initial impact due to bumper injury.
  2. Intra-abdominal or intra-thoracic injuries (secondary injury by the grill, hood, or fender)
  3. Contra-lateral head injury: This is caused as the child is thrown to the opposite side.

Note: Bumper fracture is different from injury. Bumper fracture is a comminuted fracture of the lateral condyle of the tibia.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old lady comes for a routine check-up at 34 weeks of gestation when her blood pressure is found to be 170/118 mmHg. Her urine analysis shows proteinuria 3+. Which of the following statements are true about the management of this situation?
  1. Oral Captopril can be used as a second-line drug.
  2. Labetalol is safe in asthmatics and cardiac failure patients.
  3. The maximum dose of labetalol that can be given is 300 mg.
  4. Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice.
  5. Sodium nitroprusside is the first-line drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia with hypertensive crisis (BP>160/110 mmHg). Intravenous Labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling blood pressure in severe pre-eclampsia and the maximum dose that can be given is 300 mg. Therefore, options 3 and 4 are correct. 

Drugs used in the management of hypertensive crisis.

Drug Onset of Action  Dose schedule  Maximum dose  Maintainance Dose 
Labetalol 5 mins 10-20 mg IV every 10 mins  300 mg IV 40 mg/hr
Hydralazine 10 mins 5 mg IV every 30 mins  30 mg IV 10 mg/hr
Nifedipine 10 mins  10-20 mg oral, can be repeated in 30 mins  240 mg/24 hours  4-6 hour intervals 
Nitroglycerin 0.5-5mins  5 mcg/min IV Short-term therapy when other drugs failed  
Sodium Nitroprusside  0.5-5mins  0.25-5 mcg/kg/min IV Short-term therapy when other drugs failed  

 

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and is hence contraindicated in pregnancy.

Labetalol is avoided in women having asthma or cardiac failure.

Sodium nitroprusside is only given after treatment with other drugs has failed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of headache, impaired memory, and visual disturbances. He has a history of genital ulcers from many years ago for which he did not seek appropriate treatment. Further evaluation reveals CSF analysis positive for VDRL screening. Which of the following findings is observed in the pupils in response to light?

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
Pupils accommodate but do not react.

questions.solution:
Pupils accommodate but do not react to light.

The clinical features of the patient are suggestive of neurosyphilis. The type of pupillary response seen in reaction to light is known as the Argyll Robertson pupil.

Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) is a feature of neurosyphilis that includes general paresis and tabes dorsalis. Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) results from damage to the relay paths in the tectum between the afferent and efferent tracts that interrupt pupillary light reflex. But the ventral pathway of the pupillary near reflex is spared, resulting in an intact accommodation reflex. 

Clinical features in the eyes include an intact accommodation reflex, i.e eyes converge and constrict on seeing a near object. Light reflexes are absent, which means they do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light). This is also known as light-near dissociation. These patients also have bilateral small irregular pupils. Optic atrophy is another common feature of tabes. 

Treatment of neurosyphilis is with aqueous crystalline penicillin G for 10–14 days or aqueous procaine penicillin G plus oral probenecid, both for 10–14 days. Patients who have penicillin allergy are desensitised and then treated with penicillin.

Related Pearl: Sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve supply to iris muscles

  • Dilator pupillae/radial muscle of iris: Sympathetic postganglionic nerves from cervical ganglion.
  • Constrictor pupillae/circular muscle of iris: Parasympathetic postganglionic nerves from ciliary ganglion (Edinger Westphal nucleus).

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her son to the doctor. She says that her son complains that he does not like the school environment and scores poor grades. On further history taking, it was found that the boy attends a sports club after school and excels in sports. What is the defense mechanism seen in this boy?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the boy compensates for the dislike and poor performance in school by excelling in sports, the defense mechanism involved here is compensation. In this type, the person unconsciously deals with fear or conflict by putting extreme effort into some other area of his life.

Other examples of compensation defense mechanism include excessive bodybuilding to prevent the feeling of inferiority, a patient with dementia noting down excessive details in his diary, etc.

Other options:

Option B- In splitting, the person unconsciously categorizes self or others as either good or bad, without actually considering the whole range of qualities. 

Option C- In suppression, the person voluntarily stops focussing on the thought, conflict. Eg. A person stops focussing on the quarrel in-home while he is working in the office.

Option D- In rationalization, the person provides a logical explanation for irrational behavior. It is motivated by unacceptable, unconscious wishes. Eg. A student blames his teacher for getting low marks in the exam.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with hip pain after a fall. X-ray reveals a fracture of the neck of her femur. Which of the following instruments is best suited for cutting bone while performing McMurray's osteotomy for her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the instruments given, image C represents an osteotome that can be used to cut bone while performing an osteotomy.

Osteotome-

An osteotome has both sides beveled. It is used for cutting bone.

Ex:

  • McMurray's osteotomy for fracture of neck of femur. 
  • Corrective osteotomy for genu varum and genu valgum. 

Other options:

Image A is the periosteal elevator. It is used to elevate the periosteum as nerves, and vessels are generally on this plane, and once this has been elevated the surgeon is on a safer plane.

Image B is a curette used for curetting a cavity in bone or removing fibrous tissue from ends of fracture; used in enchondroma, GCT, osteomyelitis.

Image D is bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting on round bone surfaces or making round holes in bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: Given below are four main strategies involved in moderating the role of socio-cultural contact in health. These are strategies of ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the various strategies of cultural contact. This is also known as acculturation.

Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people. This phenomenon is also known as culture contact. This can happen in the following ways:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Religious propagation
  • Education
  • Conquest

The strategies of acculturation:

  • Assimilation is a specific type of acculturation strategy characterized by the acquisition of host culture alongside the loss of heritage culture.
  • Separation refers to splitting.
  • Integration is integrating others' cultures.
  • Marginalization is the internalization of the host culture. 

Other options:

Options A and C: Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by society.

Option B: The role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

Note: Socialization is defined as a process by which man acquires beliefs, customs, traditions, and prejudices of society due to his everyday interaction with people of the society.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following phases of the hair cycle starting with the phase corresponding to hair growth:
  1. Catagen
  2. Anagen
  3. Telogen
  4. Kenogen
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of hair growth is Anagen, Catagen, Telogen, and Kenogen. 

The hair cycle is a repetitive sequence of growing and resting phases of hair follicles. Anagen is the active period of hair growth. The duration of this phase determines the final length of the hair.

Epithelial cell division declines and ceases at the end of the anagen phase and hair follicles enter into an involutiontary phase called catagen. The proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle is involuted by apoptosis during this phase.

The telogen phase is the time gap between the completion of follicular regression and the onset of the next anagen phase.

The shedding of club hair occurs through an active process termed exogen.

In the human scalp, kenogen indicates the interval in which the hair follicle remains empty after the telogen hair has been shed and before a new anagen hair emerges.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.
